feed.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT

entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
In the realm of Bitcoin transactions, the sighash mechanism plays a pivotal role in defining how transaction outputs are signed to prove ownership of bitcoins. There are six canonical SIGHASH types recognized in the current implementations, namely 1, 2, 3, 0x81, 0x82, and 0x83. Despite this, within the consensus rules, all 256 potential SIGHASH types are considered valid and distinct. This opens up a vulnerability where an adversarial miner could leverage non-standard SIGHASH types to undermine efforts at optimizing transaction verification through caching, necessitating the computation of a new transaction digest for each signature verification operation, even in scenarios not utilizing OP_CODESEPARATOR.
The proposition of rejecting OP_CODESEPARATOR, along with the FindAndDelete function and non-standard SIGHASH types via a soft fork, is discussed as a preventive measure against such optimization attacks. However, this approach encounters limitations with the advent of next-generation SIGHASH types which are anticipated to include a broader array of standard types. Moreover, the significance of sighash cache diminishes with the introduction of segregated witness (segwit), which addresses the legacy quadratic hashing issue, rendering the caching method obsolete for efficiency improvements in the new SIGHASH framework.
Despite the outdated necessity for sighash caching and the evolving landscape of SIGHASH types, the utility of OP_CODESEPARATOR in certain applications maintains its relevance among some users. The debate surrounding OP_CODESEPARATOR is nuanced, with prevailing criticisms against its implementation in legacy scripts. While there is a general inclination towards deprecating OP_CODESEPARATOR in legacy contexts, it's advocated that decisions regarding its use should be considered on a case-by-case basis, highlighting the complexity of balancing technological advancements with backward compatibility and user needs in the development of Bitcoin's protocol.
